discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
To strengthen interferer filtering in a Cisco CMX 10.6.2 solution and protect it from bursts of short-lived interferers, the engineer should configure the following two parameters:

A. Intensity Cutoff
C. Duty Cycle Cutoff

Explanation:
Intensity Cutoff: This parameter sets a threshold for the signal strength (RSSI) of interferers. Signals below this threshold are ignored, helping to filter out weak or irrelevant interferers.

Duty Cycle Cutoff: This parameter defines the minimum duty cycle an interferer must have to be considered significant. Short-lived interferers with low duty cycles are filtered out, reducing the impact of transient interference.

These two parameters work together to ensure that only persistent and strong interferers are flagged, protecting the system from short-lived interference bursts.

From Cisco CMX release 10.6.2, Interferers filtering is strengthened to protect Cisco CMX from burst of short lived interferers. For effective interferer filtering results, we recommend that you set the interferer filtering parameters for Duty Cycle Cutoff (Interferer) and Severity Cutoff (Interferer) correctly. For more information, see Setting Filtering Parameters. With this change, short lived interferers would not be tracked by Cisco CMX and moved under Not Tracked category in the System tab > Settings > Tracking window.

questions.question_text: An engineer is configuring location services with a Cisco CMX 10.6.2 solution. The engineer must strengthen interferer filtering so that Cisco CMX is protected from bursts of short-lived interferes. Which two interferer-filtering parameters must be configured to meet the requirement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
n an IEEE 802.1X authentication framework, there are three main components:

Supplicant: The client device (e.g., a laptop or smartphone) requesting access to the network.

Authenticator: The network device (e.g., an AP or switch) that controls access to the network and acts as an intermediary between the supplicant and the authentication server.

Authentication Server: Typically a RADIUS server, which verifies the credentials of the supplicant and informs the authenticator whether to grant or deny access.

Since the APs are deployed in autonomous mode and are responsible for enforcing network access control, they must act as the authenticator in the 802.1X process. The APs will relay authentication requests from the supplicant (corporate users) to the RADIUS server (authentication server) and enforce the access decision.

Selected Answer: C
AP is right answer

questions.question_text: An engineer deploys APs in autonomous mode to provide corporate and guest access in several retail locations. Remote authentication with IEEE 802.1X is configured to ensure a secure wireless connection for corporate users. Which component must be configured as the authenticator?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The allow AAA override setting must be enabled on the WLAN to allow the policy to work correctly. This setting ensures that the Cisco ISE (Identity Services Engine) can apply the URL redirection and other attributes (such as ACLs) defined in the RADIUS response to the client. In this case, the RADIUS response includes a URL redirect for BYOD devices that are not registered to the Mobile Device Manager (MDM).

Explanation of the options:
A. static IP tunneling: This is used for assigning static IP addresses to clients through tunneling and is unrelated to URL redirection or AAA override.

B. allow AAA override: This is correct. Enabling this setting allows the WLC to accept and apply attributes (such as URL redirection and ACLs) sent by the RADIUS server (Cisco ISE) in the Access-Accept message.

C. RADIUS profiling: This is used for device profiling based on RADIUS attributes but is not required for URL redirection or AAA override.

D. Aironet IE: This is used for Cisco Aironet-specific information elements in the wireless frames and is unrelated to URL redirection or AAA override.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A company is implementing Cisco ISE and IBN for their WLAN. The pictured IBN profile is applied to BYOD devices that are not registered to the Mobile Device Manager. Which advanced setting must be enabled on the WLAN to allow the policy to work correctly?

//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An event company must gather location-tracking details of wireless clients at an event where clients will be given free guest access to the Wi-Fi. A network engineer must integrate a Cisco WLC with a Cisco CMX server. Which command must be run?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. [cmxadmin@cmx]# cmxctl config controllers add

Explanation:
This command is used to add a WLC to the Cisco CMX server. It ensures that the CMX server can communicate with the WLC and collect location data from the associated access points.

The other options are not valid commands for this purpose

comments.content:
Explanation of the options:
A. Change the data retention settings to 5 seconds:

Data retention settings in Cisco PI control how long data is stored, not how frequently it is updated. This will not resolve the issue of delayed client information.

B. Use a different browser to access the web interface:

The issue is not related to the browser or the GUI performance. The problem lies in the lack of real-time updates from the WLC to Cisco PI.

C. Enable client Assoc/Disassoc and Auth/Deauth SNMP traps on the controller:

This is correct. Enabling these SNMP traps ensures that the WLC sends real-time notifications to Cisco PI about client association, disassociation, authentication, and deauthentication events. This allows Cisco PI to display current client information.

D. Optimize the Cisco Prime Infrastructure database:

While database optimization can improve overall performance, it will not address the specific issue of delayed client information updates.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The issue described is that the client detail information in Cisco Prime Infrastructure (PI) is not current and is delayed by up to 5 minutes. This delay is often caused by the lack of real-time updates from the Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) to Cisco PI. Enabling client Assoc/Disassoc and Auth/Deauth SNMP traps on the WLC ensures that Cisco PI receives immediate notifications about client connection and disconnection events, providing up-to-date client information.

comments.content: Oops, I did read "is performing as expected" in the question, so scratch above.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D is correct, follow this link and search for "compact the Prime Infrastructure Database", under How to improve the performance of Prime Infrastructure.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/net_mgmt/prime/infrastructure/3-4/admin/guide/bk_CiscoPrimeInfastructure_3_4_AdminGuide/bk_CiscoPrimeInfastructure_3_4_AdminGuide_chapter_0100.html

Selected Answer: C
The issue described suggests that the client detail information displayed in Cisco Prime Infrastructure (PI) is not current and is up to 5 minutes old. To resolve this issue, one needs to ensure that Cisco Prime Infrastructure is receiving real-time updates regarding client states and connected access points.

The correct action to resolve this issue is:

C. Enable client Assoc/Disassoc and Auth/Deauth SNMP traps on the controller.

Enabling client Assoc/Disassoc and Auth/Deauth SNMP traps on the controller allows the controller to send real-time notifications to Cisco Prime Infrastructure whenever clients associate, disassociate, authenticate, or deauthenticate from the wireless network. This ensures that Cisco Prime Infrastructure has up-to-date information about client connectivity status and the access points they are associated with.

Therefore, option C is the appropriate action to resolve the issue of outdated client detail information in Cisco Prime Infrastructure.

questions.question_text: An engineer attempts to troubleshoot client connectivity issues in Cisco Prime Infrastructure. The Cisco Prime Infrastructure GUI is performing as expected, but the client detail information that is displayed is not current. The displayed client state and connected AP are up to 5 minutes old. Which action resolves this issue?

choices.A: Change the data retention settings to 5 seconds.
choices.C: Enable client Assoc/Disassoc and Auth/Deauth SNMP traps on the controller.
choices.B: Use a different browser to access the web interface.
choices.D: Optimize the Cisco Prime Infrastructure database.
